everyone is so busy this is really important because if it's too hard no
one's going to get involved and no one's going to attend and the fourth opportunity how are we
providing opportunities for others to get involved because that's what community is all about
and then it's really important to create inclusive spaces so inclusive I can never say this word

makes it so much more enjoyable and meaningful for them name tags can be daggy but it can make

that I was part of created a little program called mini mentoring and it was such a great idea and they invited any
first-time attendees to an event to come 15 minutes earlier and they connected them with one of our regulars
who'd been to lots of events just for 15 minutes before the event started with the purpose of creating that connection
of one person that they know but then the regular their job was to go and introduce them to more people and it was

value know your target market what is going to be valuable to them and who are you

customers often ask me what companies are doing well in the Learning and Development space and if there's best
practices that I recommend I created this maturity framework just to help demonstrate some of the common
steps that organizations take as they mature from a Learning and Development perspective and once again this is just
from my experience and what I'm seeing organizations doing
so companies often start out without a clear training strategy employers are responsible for their own training
capability and generally budgets and time are pretty limited if there's any often there's no dedicated person
appointed to look after this holistically now all of these levels have pros and
cons there is no 100 right answer so the pros at this level is that from a
company perspective there's no investment required so there's no money or head count being allocated the
ownership and responsibility is fully on the employees to manage their own Learning Journey
and it's also seen from by managers as just-in-time learning so when an employee needs something they'll figure
it out they'll go learn it themselves from a cons perspective it can be seen
by employees as too hard the owners is completely on them where do they start what's available
it can be really hard for them to prioritize time to do training when it's not structured and it's not a planned
company endorsed thing are they expected to do it in their own time can they take time off there's a lot of this
uncertainty that makes it even harder and expectations it's kind of twofold one is that employees do expect that
companies will invest in their training and development now it's absolutely an expectation and on the flip side at this
level there's a lack of clear expectations on what in what training employees can access and how they access
it so is there a process of how to apply for training for money or for time once
again it just becomes too hard and it often doesn't happen
as companies grow they focus more on employee engagement retention and the need for attraction strategies and
becoming an employer of choice it's at this stage they'll often appoint someone to focus on people and culture
which generally includes training as well sometimes this can be another leader in the business and not a dedicated role it
just depends the first things generally implemented will be onboarding training plans to
ensure that new employees have the skills and the training to perform their role formal training options are normally
identified now as well and communicated to employees so that they can select the training that they desire in a range of
different modalities and then high level themes of skills are identified and champions to encourage
and drive training across these themes the pros to this is generally it's much
faster onboarding so if there's a clear where to start plan that employees can access to upskill and they're faster to
be productive there's a lot more empowerment at this stage there's a dedicated role for
support and process so they set expectations so that employers can find it easier to access training and they're
empowered it might include a budget per person or a number of training days per person
and simplification having clearly defined training options provided themes and pathways are defined so it's easier
for employees to progress their learning and connect with others that are on that same Learning Journey
it's still a siled approach often at this stage so it can be one person making a lot of these decisions
responsible for all the pathways so they may not be across everything and they also may not have full decision making
capabilities the training can often be quite generic and not customized or personalized
and the onus is still on the individual to some extent so they can slip through the cracks it can still be hard to find
time and hard to get motivated to study on their own
so this then progresses to a more strategic maturity level with executive sponsorship and a clear investment of
time and budget for Learning and Development at this stage a gap analysis is conducted across the teams and the
organization and holistic training plans are implemented with formalized learning communities otherwise known as
communities of practice or guilds this ensures that as the teams change and grow the organization has the skills
needed to succeed and can hire a succession plan accordingly this is often the time that a formal graduate
program is implemented as well one of the main Pros is lower
performance risk so because there are clearly defined skills gaps across the teams and individuals
they're they're addressed and this feeds into capability succession planning and promotion as well
this is where you see a really big Improvement as well on attraction and retention because this forms part of the
employer value proposition and knowledge sharing we know knowledge sharing can be really difficult across
organizations so retaining knowledge has a massive impact on organization success
this level some of the things in this level are really still only certain suited to certain types of organizations
so it may not be you know suitable for a very small business so there's different
things that will make it more applicable and time and budget investment is obviously going to be a focus here that
may stop some organizations being able to do it and then finally the bee's knees of
Learning and Development in organizations and this is where there's a clear culture of continuous learning and Innovation learning mechanisms form
part of onboarding projects Sprints performance feedback loops they feed into promotion Frameworks capability
Frameworks and career development pathways and importantly Learning and Development impact is measured and reported on at an
executive level this is also where you'll see learning as part of the culture Manifesto you
know one of the key core values and it's embedded into recognition for behaviors
the pros at this level is obviously retention you know has a has a big impact with this type of culture it's a
safety-file environment with continuous learning and objective performance and promotion processes which is really
important countless studies show that a culture of innovation and providing time to
innovate embedding that time to innovate has a huge correlation on business growth and success and measuring

but measuring a culture of learning and Innovation and the exact level sees this as a really important component of
success so you've got full support
there's going to still be a key person risk at this level right because when you've got exact support it's great but
what happens if that exact that exact changes or moves or leaves and new exact comes in that have a different strategy
it can all get thrown out quite quickly and then also retaining flexibility so
this kind of structure and programmatic approach can lead to rigidity as well so making sure that there's a flexor a
flexible and agile approach is still really important so as I said this is my take on maturity
levels and the pros and cons at each stage but companies can have a complete mix of these different levels it's not a

across organizations so another example of a training

that the AWS skills Guild obviously has a cloud Focus as you can imagine but this

another high-level framework that you can use as a base when building out these training plans is this one so this

so no matter which level of maturity your organization is at you can create a training community

this works as an internal or an external program we run it as a bit of a combo so
people can actually join externally or internally and as I mentioned this zero line we've

so this is a framework for people who don't have time during at working hours or can't take time off during working
hours they need extra motivation and structure to study in their own time and
of course support and fun so once again you can create a similar thing for your organization with minimal
to no budget we definitely run ours on a shoestring so there's two main program structures
that I'm going to talk you through each with the same principles the first is more structured so it's over a set
number of weeks in this case it's eight weeks and each week is broken down into online training modules weekly sessions
with mentors that we refer to as Q as but you might call them lunch and learns or just study sessions it's basically
where someone who is a champion or a subject matter expert helps the team and answers questions while they're doing
the training I found it really easy to find these Champions and mentors because people do
want to help and give back I have over 150 mentors globally that volunteer for these 30 to 45 minute
sessions to help people learn the more you have the more you can
rotate because once again we need to make it easy for people to help so some of my mentors will only do one 30-minute
session every second month so it's a very small time investment but if you have enough of them then there's a lot
of flexibility what I've seen for some organizations is Friday lunch and learn sessions they
work really well you can BYO lunch or even better you can get your your company to provide lunch for you
and it's a casual session so mentors don't need to prepare there's no homework they need to find time to do
because who has the time it's just an opportunity where people can ask questions about what they're learning
and get some advice it's really important to have some sort
of collaboration tool that you use across both of these Frameworks that I'm going to talk to having a space where people can ask
questions and support and help each other as they study is really great for building connection and also for
motivating each other to keep going we include our mentors on these channels as well but what we find is that people
actually have answered and helped each other before our mentors even get to answering the question which is really cool
if the program has a specific completion or an exam goal then we tie in some exam preparation sessions towards the end of
the program and then we also in these sessions it will be helping people understand
expectations the format of the exam doing some practice questions together most of you have probably done a cert
and you know that uh there's a little bit of a trick to how you answer the questions so practicing and getting tips
for first-timers is really important and then one of the key things is celebrating success in Milestones having
a get-together or a few drinks or some swag or some prizes makes it even more fun
um also tying in some panel events with some value add activities like leadership you know leadership panel or
a career panel I try to do this normally in about the middle of the framework just to kind of get everybody re-motivated and make sure everyone's
still still on the journey think about leveraging your vendors or your partners for mental roles if you
don't have enough internal mentors and the special guest speakers at these panel type events and definitely for
swag I know AWS do offer up that type of support for most of our customers
so where you would use this very structured framework is for people who are at the same are at a the same level
of knowledge or experience or that are capable of working to the same time frame to complete the training so this
program that we run has no minimum requirements or experience needed everyone's working at the same Pace over
one to two hours per week so it's quite slow easy to digest doesn't take up a lot of people's time but once again they
stay motivated by the community aspect the other framework that we have is a
less structured framework so this is good if you have people that are at different levels of experience and some of them may want to go faster or slower
and there's a lot more flexibility for people to tailor it to to how they want to work so the mentor and Champion
component of the structure is still the same with weekly or four nightly sessions the main difference is that the
training material isn't broken down into a week by week format it's provided for people just to digest at their own pace
the longer program is generally more advanced training so we also would add to this some additional kind of Hands-On
workshops every you know once a month or however often you want to do it we do them monthly or bi-monthly and that
helps embed the more complex learning for people as well and then we'd still have a celebration or graduation type
event but we'd schedule that in like quarterly or six monthly Milestones as opposed to having it at a set completion
time because there is no completion time so this one for us has an average completion time of sort of 13 or so
weeks um spending two to three hours per week on the content but some people will smash this out in four weeks other
people will take 20 weeks so it does really provide that flexibility for people
same as with the other structure it's ideal to offer some sort of carrot for those that complete the objective
whether the objective is the exam or the project outcome or completing a specific course
having this at the end also gives you a mechanism to report on the outcomes from the program as you capture the evidence
as such of people's completion so I get people to email me a screenshot of their past exam or ask them to tag me on
LinkedIn where they're putting it on LinkedIn and this is a good way to get further investment into your program to
show that what the outcomes have been and that it's been successful and it's also important to run satisfaction
surveys as well as another data point to gauge engagement but also to iterate and
improve the program so a quick end-to-end example is the um
hapori wahine Cloud up program that I was in Auckland for last week this was a program that I had three months to
create and launch with a target of training 300 women we consulted lots of New Zealand locals
organizations and people on the ground to get feedback on what they thought would and wouldn't work in this
environment as we've talked about knowing your target market is really important and tailoring your content and
events to suit your target market is really important so we created a four-week flexible
learning program with a mix of face-to-face events and also virtual and self-paced events as well
we launched the program with a six-week ramp up time for promotion which is ideal once again four weeks I would say
is the minimum six weeks even better we created social media tiles and blurbs
and engaged as many Community groups and locals with networks as we could and ask them to promote the program via LinkedIn
and Via emails we had no paid marketing or PR assistance to support the program
and we had over 500 women register by the kickoff last week which was amazing smashed our Target which was always good
and it was really great to be in New Zealand for the first week of this program to get to meet all the community
of women we had about 50 come to our face-to-face events and then we had about 200 on the virtual events and got
lots of great feedback as with all free communities like I was saying earlier the drop-off rate was pretty much
exactly 50 so we ended up with about 240 on our slap Channel our community Channel
but on the last day at the face-to-face event we stood in a circle and gave everybody the option to say what they'd
gained from the experience every single woman spoke and shared their stories about what they'd gained
which was incredible and one woman cried as she told us that she'd been a stay-at-home mum for the
last five years and she was so overwhelmed at the opportunity to be part of this community what she learned
the confidence that she'd gained and the network of women she'd developed friendships with this is an isolated feedback and it's
